Topic.Title: How can I invest in Alibaba Group?

Message.Msg: Owning Yahoo is a better way to buy into Alibaba Group than owning Softbank. Yahoo's market cap is $22 billion and owns 24% of Alibaba Group. Softbank's Market cap is US$41 billion and owns 35% of Alibaba Group. Yahoo's stock is more heavily weighted in Alibaba Group than Softbank's. But then you should have know that if you had actually done any research on Softbank, grey.

Topic.Title: How can I invest in Alibaba Group?

Message.Msg: Owning Softbank is a better way to invest in Alibaba Group. With Yahoo you are stuck with a portal that has no Cloud, or mobile strategy and that is loosing Display ads to Facebook. Yahoo has no growth and is liquidating itself. With Softbank you also get, in addition to the Alibaba Group stake, a stake in one of the fastest growing mobile phone companies in Japan which is changing the way the majors do business and you get a rider on a remade Sprint in the USA. With both you also get a ride on YahooJapan. But then you should have know that if you had actually done any research on Softbank, bflat.

Message.Title: Duke Fails to Pay Property Taxes
Message.Msg: On November 28, 2012 Duke paid just $19.3 million of a $35 Million tax bill from Citrus County, Florida. The unexpected and last minute surprise has basically shut down the county that depends heavily on those taxes. The small county, in central Florida, has been receiving a similar amount for the past 15 years from Florida Power/Progress Energy. The county population is 60% seniors over the age of 60. The community is now facing massive cuts to their budget that is already 2 months into it's budget year. Sheriff's servces are being cut, some schools may need be closed, there will be county employee reduction, all or most of senior services will be slashed, there will need to be substantial layoffs in most all services and many businesses will have to reduce services and staff. Unemployment is expected to rise in this mostly residential community. The county questions why Progress Energy (Duke Energy) waited until it's tax roll was certified on Oct. 2 to contest the assesment that has long standing history and court reviewed approval dating to 1998.

Message.Title: Think about it: is this a conspiracy?
Message.Msg: Yahoo has made steady up moves in the last 2 months, the short hedge funds have been trapped. What could they do? hire someone to write bash articles such as overbought, hire some analysts to cut ratings? what else? A lawsuit from Mexico? 2.7 Billions?? did any U.S. company paid any penny to Mexico court before?? Nope. But if this is a conspiracy related to shortsellers or hedgefunds which either wants to cover short or get shares at cheap, then their purpose might be partially reached as the shares are taking a hit right now: they are buying??? If this is the case, then YAHOO should contact FBI for an investigation about who really initiate the lawsuit and anyone else related. Remembering FBI is currently involved with HPQ acquisition fraud??

Topic.Title: can yahoo buy back some shares in the AH?

Message.Msg: Yahoo cannot buy on or before the opening or during or after the last half hour of scheduled trading. And the company's bid may not exceed the highest current bid or last sale price, whichever is higher. See SEC Rule 10b-18

Message.Title: This law suit news is confusing-comments please
Message.Msg: If you read yhoo's press release they say the claims are without merit. Did they not know of the suit before hand? In mexico do they give awards before the suit goes full cycle? Yahoo said its a non final judgment? Since when do courts had out judgments that are not final? The press make it sound like yahoo will hand over 2.7b next week. Comments anyone

Topic.Title: This law suit news is confusing-comments please

Message.Msg: 2.5 billion to Yellow Pages in Mexico - I don't think so.

Topic.Title: This law suit news is confusing-comments please

Message.Msg: True it is a non-final judgement. But, there is a big difference between US and Mexican laws. The laws of Mexico are based on Spanish law. If a case is filed against you, you are guilty and subject to the courts ruling accordingly. You are deemed guilty and you must prove your innocence. I am not sure of the length of time before the court makes a final ruling but that which i am familiar with is a term of five (5) years. Spanish based law is a little different and totally bias to the first to file.

Topic.Title: This law suit news is confusing-comments please

Topic.Title: This law suit news is confusing-comments please

Message.Msg: Went to Yahoo Mexico, something i had missed became evident. Breach of contract, Breach of promise are two seperate issues according to spanish law. And then there is loss of profits. At the moment is is little more than a can of worms. Will it turn into a barrel of snakes? Time will tell.
